content:
So we need to
0) find where we were supposed to report to T-libs
1) tell them what we have been up to
2) ask them whether they want a PR to rustc or an RFC draft posted first... or simultaneously? either one.
What's a T-lib?
libs team.
Ok. How do the reports help them and us?
Oh, T-lib == Team libs
(It's referencing the T-libs label on github.)

Nominally, T-libs are our """bosses""", this project exists by their will and nominally under their oversight, and will continue until it turns in all the relevant artifacts, after which those will be maintained by T-libs. https://github.com/rust-lang/project-portable-simd/blob/master/CHARTER.md
reviewing our charter, though, if we take those as an "in order" thing, we actually already have an answer: the RFC comes dead last, prior to stabilization.
nonetheless, we should tell them what we're up to.
And by bosses, I really just mean we definitely don't ship to stable without their signoff.

Yeah, my understanding is we should draft an RFC but it only actually gets merged when we intend to stabilize. We could always just open the PR for getting into nightly and see what happens :smiling_devil:
But agreed that we should be doing things "right" whatever that is
Also, part of the purpose of the "public performance" of reporting is to broadcast our status.
Since everyone involved is just volunteering their time it's more for the sake of the health of rust and making it easier for everyone involved and not so much process for the sake of process
yeah.
Which imo might just be a notification (to the world,not just the lib teams) that we have a good working prototype and are basically ready for inclusion in the compiler
Might be good to do everything in the nightly inclusion PR just so it's more accessible than some dark corner of zulip or markdown somewhere
Though I am curious if we should actually be reporting regular status or not, in some sense our status has hardly changed in months unless we go into needlessly technical detail
i mean if they're interested anyone can check the zulip stream
It seems, reviewing what was said here and in the charter, we don't bother with an RFC just to get the lib into Nightly, does that seem right?

@Jubilee From a T-libs perspective, I don't think an RFC is even the ideal way to do a "check-in / design review"; an informal document and a conversation in a meeting seems preferable for that. And to get into nightly, a PR seems fine.
That said, starting to draft an RFC seems like a really good idea, and a draft of that RFC might form part of a document that helps drive a check-in / design review meeting.
But yeah, from a libs perspective, RFCs are for stabilization, nightly works via PRs and other documents and meetings.

Thanks for the input @Josh Triplett - I'm a bit new to the RFC process. I'm guessing this is a good guide for RFC's
https://rust-lang.github.io/rfcs/#rust-rfcs
It is, but it's also worth noting that different teams use RFCs a little differently.
For instance, lang and compiler have the MCP process as a way to start a conversation and work effort, while libs an cargo don't have that (but we've thought about introducing it).
And lang tends to operate by "everything needs either an RFC or MCP", while libs doesn't mind doing nightly-only changes via PRs.
Oh neat, thanks for explaining.
Also, does this mean we have to update stuff?
